title: The most popular fact checks of March
subtitle: The monthly roundup is topped by our look at the rallying cry of protesters in the wake of the Ferguson shooting.
author: www.washingtonpost.com
vclaim:
We also have a two-way tie for fifth place — both of which just edged out a fact check of Hillary Rodham Clinton’s news conference on her unusual e-mail system while she was at the State Department. In fact, we’re pleased to say this was a banner month for The Fact Checker, smashing all previous traffic records.

1: ‘Hands up, don’t shoot’ did not happen in Ferguson

“Hands up, don’t shoot” came to symbolize the need to hold law enforcement accountable in the wake of the shooting death of Michael Brown at the hands of police officer Darren Wilson. But an extensive Justice Department investigation concluded that Wilson did not know whether Brown was armed, that he acted out of self-defense and that he was justified in killing Brown. The majority of witnesses told federal investigators that the initial claims that Brown’s hands were up were not accurate. We concluded that “hands up, don’t shoot” was worthy of Four Pinocchios.

2: Ted Cruz’s claim that there has been ‘zero’ global warming in 17 years

Using cherry-picked data, Cruz claimed that there has been “zero warming” or “no recorded warming” since 1998, though he later modified his comment to say there is no significant warming. It turns out that 1998 was particularly warm, because of an El Niño weather pattern. Moreover, a range of available data, including ocean heat content, data about glaciers receding, sea-level-height data and others, all point to continued global warming even after 1998. Cruz earned three Pinocchios.

3: Obama’s claim that Keystone XL oil ‘bypasses the U.S.’ earns Four Pinocchios

President Obama repeated false claims about the Keystone pipeline that had previously earned him Pinocchios, yet he managed to be even more misleading than before by suggesting that the pipeline would have no benefit for American producers. Moreover, his remarks are contradicted by the analysis of his own State Department. Thus the president earned Four Pinocchios.

Speaking to students at a South Carolina college, Obama made a number of exaggerated statements about guns, including that U.S. homicide rates are higher “by a mile” than those in other industrialized countries. He earned Three Pinocchios.

5: Is the controversial Indiana law ‘the same’ as a law backed by Obama?

Numerous readers requested a ruling on whether Indiana Gov. Mike Pence (R) was correct that the controversial Religious Freedom Restoration Act signed into law in Indiana was the same as an Illinois bill supported by then-state-Sen. Barack Obama in 1998. There is a case that the two laws are roughly similar. But there are certainly some differences — which might have become important as cases based on the law made their way through the courts. (Under pressure, the Indiana legislature amended it to address concerns the law could be used to target gays.)

Conservatives frequently cite the influence of Frank Marshall Davis, a friend of Obama’s grandfather, on the president’s thinking. We provided a definitive look at Davis’s Communist Party activities and his relationship with Obama, based on competing research by those who have spent years trying to posthumously vindicate or indict Davis. We carefully considered the facts underlying this assertion, and the evidence is slim that Marshall was a close mentor.
